Award.AwardTitle: Study of Spin-Dependent Charge Transfer through Self-Assembled Monolayers of DNA on Metal Surfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) molecules, the genetic code of life, have recently been shown to possess a surprising filtering capacity for the flow of electric charge. The charge is carried by electrons that are transmitted through each molecule. Electrons also possess an intrinsic property known as spin, and can exist in one of two (usually) equally probable states: spin up or spin down. Surprisingly, DNA molecules can filter transmitted electrons based on their spin, holding exciting implications for their use in emerging technological applications that require the generation and manipulation of spin-polarized electrical currents within the nascent field of spintronics. However, the mechanism responsible for the filtering effect remains elusive and controversial. In order to assess the practicality of DNA molecules as components in next generation spintronic devices, the parameters that have been theoretically predicted to influence electron spin-filtering capacity by DNA molecules assembled on metal surfaces must be tested and determined. The proposed research will leverage two decades worth of studies on manipulating molecular assemblies and recent advances to develop and to understand spin-polarized sources of electrons. This research will combine the fields of nanoscience, nanotechnology, spintronics, bioelectronics, and biomagnetics. Specific advances in terms of experimental tests and their results will be made widely available both through UCLA, national, and global collaborations. Deeper understanding of these effects will lead to important discoveries across disciplines; findings will be broadly disseminated via presentations, publications, and strong collaborative networks. Outreach activities will target young, underrepresented scientists and the public at large by engaging local high school teachers and students, as well as the global entertainment industry based in Southern California.

Recent observations of spin-selective phenomena involving chiral molecules prevalent in biological systems demonstrate the unique and exciting potential to utilize diamagnetic molecules for organic spintronics. In particular, unprecedented spin-selective electron transmission has been observed through self-assembled monolayers of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) adsorbed on metal surfaces. While experimental evidence has established that assembled, oriented, chiral DNA molecules have the capacity to filter electron spins at room temperature, the mechanism responsible for this phenomenon remains controversial. One community suggests that the phenomenon may be intrinsic to the molecule itself as many theoretical models attribute the observed effects to unconventional Rashba-type molecular spin-orbit coupling. In contrast, leading theory groups argue that the substrates and interfaces play major roles in spin-orbit coupling. Careful experimental tests will deconvolute the relative contributions and will establish a means to optimize spin selection and filtering. Robust figures of merit will be established to characterize spin-dependent charge transport via electrochemical methods. Molecular properties and substrate materials will be tuned systematically to test the theoretically predicted contributions to this phenomenon. Specifically, the modification of molecular chemical and electronic structures including the inclusion of heavy metal species and substrate identity will directly probe spin orbit coupling within the molecule and interface. This work will simultaneously develop a foundational understanding of spin-selective electron-molecule interactions and critically evaluate the practicability of ultimately implementing DNA and/or other chiral molecular assemblies as sources of polarized electrons in next generation organic spin electronic devices such as spin filters, spin-transfer torque magnetoresistive random access memory devices and spin-polarized organic light emitting diodes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

NSF ECCS Award #1509794

Study of Spin-Dependent Charge Transfer through Self-Assembled Monolayers of DNA on Metal Surfaces

 

In electrical circuits, charge is carried by electrons which possess an intrinsic property known as spin, and can exist in one of two (usually) equally probable states: spin up or spin down. Understanding spin-selective interactions between electrons, metals, and organic molecules is critical to improve and to control charge and spin transport, injection, and detection at metal-molecule interfaces – a necessity for the realization of faster and more efficient devices. Recently, chiral molecules, or molecules that lack a plane of structural symmetry, have been shown to selectively polarize spin-up or spin-down electrons, but the mechanism to describe this effect remains elusive. Many biomolecules are chiral, including proteins and deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) due to the helical arrangement of the atoms that make up these molecules. Our work demonstrates that DNA preferentially conducts electrons of one spin state over another at room temperature. We identified the polarization direction of the electron’s spin in this charge transfer process through robust analytical characterization techniques. Our results suggest that chiral, organic molecule assemblies may be viable components in next-generation electronic devices to generate and to manipulate spin-polarized currents.

 

 

Intellectual Merit

We have internalized the necessity of repeated measurements, unbiased statistical analysis of large data sets, and careful design of control experiments in the study of the chiral-induced spin selectivity effect, which describes spin-dependent and enantioselective interactions between electrons and chiral molecules. Identifying the preferred spin-velocity relationship for electrons confined to move along helical potentials, such as through a right-handed DNA helix, has proven to be difficult, with studies disagreeing on the preferred polarization orientation. Under ambient conditions, measurement error or sample variation present a challenge to conclude whether charge transmission is enhanced or suppressed at ferromagnetic metal – chiral molecule interfaces when the magnetization orientation state of the ferromagnetic metal is changed; which is the typical experimental strategy to detect spin filtration in charge transfer through adsorbed chiral molecules.

 

To elucidate the preferred spin polarization direction in DNA-mediated charge transport, we utilized the strengths of our group, namely molecular self-assembly, large-scale (micron to centimeter) molecular patterning, and data processing and analysis from information-rich images, to investigate the effect via fluorescence microscopy. Fluorescent perylenediimide (PDI) derivatives were precisely incorporated within hydrophobic pockets in double-stranded DNA helices, and the DNA/dye complexes were patterned on ferromagnetic substrates that could be magnetized parallel or antiparallel to the DNA strands. Upon photoexcitation, the dyes may fluoresce, or when well-coupled to the DNA, display competitive quenching due to charge transfer to the underlying magnetic surface. Because charge injection into ferromagnetic materials is spin dependent, a dependence of the fluorescence intensity on substrate magnetization direction is indicative of spin filtering, where lower fluorescence intensities in our system correspond to higher degrees of charge quenching and transfer from the dye to the substrate. A hallmark of our work is the use of patterned arrays that provide background measurements in every image, enabling more accurate determination of substrate magnetization-dependent emission. Moreover, the use of image segmentation algorithms maximize the quantity of data used in calculating fluorescence intensities and eliminates user bias in drawing line profiles to extract quantitative information from images.

 

 

Broader Impacts

Through our study of spin-dependent DNA-mediated charge transfer, we have expanded molecular patterning capabilities using tabletop techniques established by our group onto ferromagnetic materials specifically designed with perpendicular magnetic orientation, designed in collaboration with Professor Eric Fullerton (UCSD), opening a unique avenue toward the study of controllable patterned arrays of molecular magnets and interfacial effects that may arise upon organic molecule assembly on ferromagnetic thin films.

 

In order to quantify minute differences in fluorescence intensity in patterned DNA/dye assemblies on ferromagnetic substrates, we employed image segmentation algorithms developed in collaboration with Professor Andrea Bertozzi (UCLA). Outside of our investigation of spin-selective phenomena in charge transfer by surface-adsorbed molecules, our demonstration of the capability to distinguish statistically significant differences in fluorescence intensities of < 1% is expected to be of particular interest across disciplines. For example, this analytical technique may be useful for quantification of relative fluorescence intensities to distinguish specific vs non-specific binding of complementary oligonucleotides in DNA microarrays, as well in materials science to investigate polarized emission from nitrogen vacancy centers in diamond.
